title: Dodgers’ Teoscar Hernández searches for ‘edge’ as he tries to right ship on season
description: Struggling outfielder has become the avatar for the Los Angeles Dodgers' inconsistency in recent months.
content:
PITTSBURGH — It’s no secret that Dave Roberts wants to see more from Teoscar Hernández.

Hernández, in many ways, has become the avatar for the Los Angeles Dodgers’ inconsistency over the last few months, and with it, the direct recipient of some of Roberts’ criticism. He’s hardly the only issue with the team at the moment, as another loss to a below-.500 team on Tuesday night showed, a 9-7 defeat to the Pittsburgh Pirates, who have scored the fewest runs in the majors as their bullpen continues to leak.

The focus has found Hernández nonetheless. Hernández’s defense has lagged to the point where it’s cost the Dodgers wins. His offensive production is at the lowest point of his career, as he entered Tuesday with a .732 OPS.

With it, several of his manager’s comments about the team have pointed directly at Hernández. Roberts has lamented his team’s propensity to wait to flip a switch on and play its best baseball, turning a nine-game division lead into a dogfight. Hernández has waxed and waned in a way that’s been difficult to pin down.

“He’s a guy that I really admire, because he can balance the fun part of baseball but also have that edge,” Roberts said. “And I think a little bit, we’ve lost a little bit of that edge over the last couple months. So I think, for me, I want to see that edge, that fight, that fire, and I’ll bet on any result. And so that’s for me, it’s like, I just want to see that.”

That’s what Roberts emphasized when Hernández sat on Sunday as part of what the manager called a “two-day reset,” with Monday’s off day to recalibrate the expectations. Hernández is an everyday player, Roberts reiterated Sunday. But the production has to match. So, he was effectively benched for the day, a blow that would’ve seemed inconceivable as the team sought so clearly to bring him back this past offseason.

Roberts said he’s had “numerous conversations” with the All-Star outfielder in hopes of establishing an equilibrium like the one he had in his first year in Los Angeles, when he was among the club’s most consistent October performers and was so beloved that he was moved to tears when speaking at the team’s World Series parade.

“Teo is a guy that we counted on a lot last year in the biggest of moments,” Roberts said. “We’re aligned. He knows his value for our ballclub. He knows my expectations of him individually. So we’re in lockstep.”

Hernández understands the frustration. Because he’s feeling it. Last year was supposed to be a launching-off point, the one that got him the long-term deal he’d wanted for years in a place where he felt comfortable.

“I want to put a little extra,” Hernández said. “When you do that, you put more pressure on yourself. We had a big year last year. This year we’ve got a lot of expectation not only for the team but for myself, personally. For me, not being the same as last year is a little frustrating. I don’t want to be like that. I want to be better than last year. But it’s baseball.”

Concerns about Hernández’s focus go away if he’s hitting. This is not a storyline if he is putting up the .840 OPS he put up a year ago, or the .933 OPS he had before landing on the injured list in May with a strained groin. That halted what was set to be a strong encore to last year’s success. So did a bruise he suffered when he fouled a ball off his left foot more than a month after returning. The resulting struggles raised one of two questions: either Hernández was still hurt (or trying to avoid reinjuring himself) or the injuries had disrupted whatever rhythm he’d had to start the season.

Both Hernández’s groin and his foot are “100 percent,” he said.

“For me, it’s more being on the field,” Hernández said. “For me, being hurt is more frustrating than having a bad year. I’d rather be on the field and having a bad year than not being on the field and just fighting back and forth.”

That still has meant moments like Tuesday, when first-inning struggles from Clayton Kershaw were exacerbated when Tommy Pham blooped a ball in Hernández’s direction. Hernández broke on it and reached the necessary distance, but still couldn’t come up with the slicing ball as two runs came home in a four-run frame. The ball had a .100 expected batting average, according to Statcast.

“He gave a good effort, just didn’t come up with it,” Roberts said. “So for me, if I see a good jump getting off the ball, good effort, I’ve got no problem with it. I really don’t.”

The response came an inning later. His swing is still not right, but he fouled off a pair of two-strike offerings from the Pirates’ Carmen Mlodzinski to stay alive. When the right-hander tried going to a well that Hernández has struggled with — breaking balls at the shins and below — Hernández stayed with the two-strike curveball and served up a single into center field. An inning later, he fouled off two more two-strike pitches before lacing a 100.2 mph fastball from Bubba Chandler into right field to bring home a run.

The big swings will come. At-bats like these are what the Dodgers need right now, though it wasn’t enough on Tuesday. There are several holes to plug right now for a team that can’t get right and has now lost nine of its last 13 against teams with losing records. All while the stakes are as high as they’ve been for the Dodgers all season.

“I don’t think we look at it winning record, losing record,” Kershaw said. “We’re just trying to win games.”

“Obviously, we didn’t play well,” Mookie Betts said. “We all know that. Don’t have to necessarily have a team come-to-Jesus about it. We’ve just got to find ways to win games.”

Hernández at least provided an encouraging sign at the plate.

“Obviously, I’m working on my swing, trying to get the consistency that I want with good contact, good at-bats and not overthinking too much,” Hernández said. “Just going there, having fun. Fight every at-bat, every pitch, and not chasing the results.”
summary: The Los Angeles Dodgers are struggling this season, with Teoscar Hernández being the central figure of the team's inconsistency. Despite a 9-7 defeat to the Pittsburgh Pirates, Hernändez's performance has been criticized for costing the team wins. His offensive performance is at the lowest point of his career, with a.732 OPS. Manager Dave Roberts has emphasized the need for an edge in the team and has had discussions with Hernainez about his role in the future. Despite this, he has been benched for a day and is seeking a two-day reset to reset expectations.
shortSummary: The Los Angeles Dodgers' Teoscar Hernández seeks to regain his former edge as manager Dave Roberts criticizes the team’s inconsistent performance and struggles.

scraped_sources.text:
LOS ANGELES — The light has flickered on and off for the Los Angeles Dodgers enough times this season to turn their manager sour.
Dave Roberts has warned against relying on flipping the switch, as his Dodgers have consistently played down to their competition, only to come to life when the circumstances call for it. The Dodgers exited San Diego last weekend with a division lead and swept the Wild Card-contending Cincinnati Reds … only to drop a series to an Arizona Diamondbacks team just trying to piece things together following a fire sale at the deadline.
Advertisement
A 5-4 walk-off win on Sunday thanks to Will Smith’s home run helped finish off a homestand on a winning note and avoid a sweep. It also left Los Angeles at 78-59 and with a two-game lead in the NL West. But it didn’t paper over what has been a concerning trend.
Over their last 31 games, the Dodgers are 11-4 against teams with winning records and 6-10 against teams below .500.
They haven’t looked good while doing it, scoring just one run through the first 18 innings they played this weekend, all while facing a pair of starters in Zac Gallen and Eduardo Rodríguez who entered with a combined 5.36 ERA in 275 innings. They’ve squandered winnable games that could’ve extended their division lead and lightened the amount of work they’ll have to accomplish in September.
Even Sunday was difficult.
“Each night, it seems like there’s something else that is not all put together in one particular game for a longer stretch,” Roberts said.
PINCH-HIT WALK-OFF HOMER? YES HE WILL. pic.twitter.com/Oo0Uz2kss3
— Los Angeles Dodgers (@Dodgers) August 31, 2025
The Dodgers opened with an early 2-0 lead against Arizona starter Brandon Pfaadt and got another brilliant start from Yoshinobu Yamamoto. But closer Tanner Scott surrendered a home run to Corbin Carroll to tie the score in the top of the eighth. It was the ninth home run Scott has allowed this season, after he only gave up six combined over the last two years.
“It’s super frustrating,” Scott said. “Just got to go out there and fix it.”
A win helped make up for it, but the frustration remains. So Roberts vented on Sunday morning, speaking for close to 10 minutes on a group that hasn’t kept its intensity and focus nearly long enough to separate itself from the competition.
“I think it’s just all upon us, to come in each day and, to be honest with you, to not get embarrassed,” Roberts said.
Advertisement
A team that spent this spring espousing the notion it could avoid the complacency that befalls many reigning World Series champions has perhaps fallen victim to it, Roberts acknowledged.
“I hate going backward and talking about last year,” Roberts said. “But when you’re playing a long season, you’re defending champions, people are coming after you, which we know and understand, it’s just hard to keep that dialed in focus every single night. That’s just reality. That’s human nature.”
Still, they are up against the clock. Just 25 games remain for the Dodgers to hold their narrow division lead over the San Diego Padres.
“You guys gotta understand, we’re human beings,” Miguel Rojas said. “And sometimes you get tired, especially mentally. And you got a lot of things going on in your life, and your year, and it’s not easy to be locked in every single time. But I feel like we made a commitment to be locked in for 25 more games, plus the 20 or whatever we need to play in the playoffs.”
“We’ve got to play well, play good baseball, take care of it,” Smith said.
Just two weeks ago, Roberts pushed against the notion that the Dodgers had a switch of sorts they could flip on when they needed it, calling it “a dangerous way to live.” Then the Dodgers flipped it on and swept the Padres at home. It flipped back off from there to the point where Roberts and veterans were openly critical about the team’s offensive approach. The group has continued to spit out inconsistent offensive results, as it has seemingly since the beginning of June.
“I do think that a flip can be switched,” Roberts said. “It doesn’t feel good for me saying it. … Whatever it is, we’ve got to do it right now. We’ve got to win today. We’ve got to play better baseball. We’ve got to play more focused baseball and then let the chips fall where they may. There’s just more in there. There just is.”
Teoscar Hernández spent Sunday afternoon on seed duty. Usually, his task of grabbing sunflower seeds to throw at Dodgers home-run hitters is a busy task; he’s usually in the lineup, and the Dodgers entered Sunday having slugged the most home runs in the National League with 201.
Advertisement
Not so much this weekend. The Dodgers did not hit a home run against an Arizona pitching staff that had allowed the 10th-most in the majors this season until the weekend’s final at-bat. And in the series finale, Hernández wasn’t in the lineup.
Hernández wasn’t originally scheduled to sit on Sunday. Had he been swinging a better bat, he might have been in the lineup for the series finale as the group looked to spruce up its overall production.
“Obviously, I’m not doing the best hitting,” Hernández said this weekend.
“Clearly, he hasn’t handled right-handed pitching,” Roberts said. Hernández has a .689 OPS in 356 plate appearances against righties this season. His utility on the roster is to hit, and he’s enduring the worst full offensive season of his career. He’s hardly the lone culprit, but he’s become a target of Roberts’ criticism of late because of his importance to where the Dodgers need to be. Maybe a two-day “reset” could help, Roberts said.
With it came a message that Roberts seemed to relay with his comments on Sunday.
“He’s an everyday guy, but I do think that where we’re at, you’ve got to perform, too, to warrant being out there every single day, regardless, right?” Roberts said.
That extends to everybody. Even Michael Conforto, who has been extended a $17 million leash despite his season-long struggles and was batting fifth on Sunday despite entering the day sporting the fifth-worst OPS (.628) among hitters with as much playing time as he’s received.
“Yeah, it does,” said Roberts, who over the course of the session laid out some of the contingencies. Tommy Edman got some work in center field on Sunday afternoon and is expected to spend some time in the outfield when he goes out on a rehab assignment this week. On those days Edman is in center, perhaps Andy Pages or Hernández could kick over to left field. Hyeseong Kim had another start in left field for Oklahoma City on Sunday in what will be the final game of his rehab assignment; he can be a left-handed hitting left field option who could potentially take at-bats from Conforto.
The pending Dodgers free agent with the biggest chance to swing his financial fortunes over the next eight weeks has thrown all of seven innings in the big leagues this season. This is not the walk year that Michael Kopech wanted. That might be irrelevant if he puts together a strong stretch run through to the end of October. Such is life for a hard-throwing reliever, who has been shut down at different times this season due to forearm, shoulder and then knee ailments before the calendar has even flipped to September.
Advertisement
“It feels like it’s been a long season,” Kopech said. “I’ve had two stints of the 60-day (injured list). You never want to go on the IL in general, but definitely I don’t want to miss this many games.”
Kopech’s right knee required surgery in July. His forearm didn’t feel right through last October and the discomfort crawled up to his shoulder through spring training. A strong month could assuage whatever medical red flags come with such a history, especially when you throw as hard as Kopech does.
His minor league rehab stint with Oklahoma City raised another red flag. The velocity was fine. The strike-throwing was not. In seven appearances, he allowed five runs, walking nine batters. His command has always been scattershot, with enough stuff in short bursts to overcome it. Still, the general lack of feel for where anything is going is why the Dodgers plan to work Kopech in slowly when he’s activated this week.
“Everything changes at this level,” Kopech said. “You come up here and you get an atmosphere of the game, you get an atmosphere of the clubhouse, the mindset of competition of playing in the direction of a championship and things like that. Timing is different in that environment than it is in any other environment. So I feel pretty good with it all. I feel healthy, and so I think a lot of that will show up as it comes.”
The Dodgers might wind up needing him more than they thought they would a few weeks ago. Brock Stewart required another cortisone injection to treat his injured shoulder. Stewart’s season is not over — he has resumed throwing — but the Dodgers need trustworthy right-handed relief options with Stewart out and Kirby Yates struggling (including allowing a three-run home run on Saturday).
Alex Vesia is progressing well from his strained right oblique and should go on a brief rehab assignment this week, and the left-hander said Sunday he’s expecting to be active at some point during the team’s next homestand.
(Top photo of Will Smith celebrating his walk-off home run against Arizona on Sunday: Jayne Kamin-Oncea / Imagn Images)

PITTSBURGH — Shohei Ohtani’s 100th home run as a Los Angeles Dodger screamed into the right field seats at PNC Park before anyone could even process it. That’s because the three-time MVP turned around the Bubba Chandler fastball at 120 mph, breaching a threshold that just five homers over the last decade of Statcast tracking have ever eclipsed. The ball cleared the 21-foot wall in right field just 3.6 seconds after it left Ohtani’s bat.
Advertisement
Ohtani is now the fastest in franchise history to reach the milestone, requiring just 294 games to pass Gary Sheffield’s mark of 399 before he cleared the century mark.
120 mph for Shohei's 100th homer as a Dodger! pic.twitter.com/iIukEIr5UP
— Los Angeles Dodgers (@Dodgers) September 2, 2025
“I’m not surprised by it,” manager Dave Roberts said recently as Ohtani neared the mark. “But I guess I was just more of, I don’t know what to expect. Just happy to have him in a Dodger uniform and see how it plays out. He’s just had an incredible run in a short period of time.”
He reached it with the hardest-hit ball of his career, joining Oneil Cruz, Giancarlo Stanton, Ronald Acuña Jr. and Aaron Judge as the only players, since 2015, to hit a home run at 120 mph or harder. It wasn’t even the hardest-hit ball in this ballpark this season, as Cruz’s record mark of 122.9 mph happened in May.
Of those home runs, none came on a pitch as hard as the 99.2 mph fastball that Ohtani pulled against Chandler.
With his 46th blast of the season, Ohtani is also still in hot pursuit of topping the career-high and franchise record mark of 54 home runs he slugged in his first year of a record-setting 10-year deal. This, all while returning to the mound: his next start is Wednesday.
(Photo: Joe Sargent / Getty Images)

DENVER — Shortly after Monday night’s debacle, Mookie Betts was in his manager’s office. The six-time Gold Glove right fielder turned shortstop had already showered and changed as media entered the visiting clubhouse at Coors Field, and the door remained open as Betts sat on the couch and talked with Los Angeles Dodgers president of baseball operations Andrew Friedman and manager Dave Roberts.
Advertisement
Betts’ transition to shortstop has been an unquestioned individual defensive success, as the 32-year-old has more than handled his own at the game’s premier position. The defense in Betts’ old position — the one he stood at when the Dodgers recorded the final out of their World Series run in October — has fallen off.
Teoscar Hernández’s inability to record an out on a ball that (according to Statcast) had a 90 percent catch probability had sunk the Dodgers in a walk-off loss to a putrid Colorado Rockies team, once again drawing attention to his right-field play that has been among the worst in baseball.
The topic of Monday night’s conversation, according to all parties involved, never touched upon right field. Rather, it was one of several check-ins Betts has had with Roberts — some of which have been visible to media — as he’s dealt with his struggles throughout the worst offensive season of his career.
“Mookie pops into my office all the time,” Roberts said. “I hope too much wasn’t made of that.”
Betts is not the only one; Freddie Freeman was spotted in Roberts’ office before Tuesday night’s contest for a brief conversation.
Betts and Friedman each independently told The Athletic before Roberts’ comments that the three were discussing the progress of Betts’ swing as he’s gone 16-for-48 (.333) over his last 12 games — and not about a possible switch at right field.
Sure enough, Betts did not replace Hernández in right field Tuesday night, as both former All-Stars assumed the same positions they started the season in.
Tonight's #Dodgers lineup at Rockies: pic.twitter.com/KOeJmJSKgT
— Los Angeles Dodgers (@Dodgers) August 19, 2025
Still, the tumultuous 24 hours at least temporarily brought back calls for Betts to return to the outfield, as he did last August for the team’s stretch run after starting that season as the team’s shortstop. Roberts said right field has not come up “at all” in conversations with Betts this season.
Advertisement
“I think that’s a fair question,” Roberts said. “But I don’t think we’re there yet.”
Roberts pointed to the lack of options in the Dodgers’ infield, which is without Tommy Edman, Hyeseong Kim, Kiké Hernández and Max Muncy. The Dodgers are reluctant to put Miguel Rojas into an everyday role at age 36, especially when he was far from 100 percent last postseason. They’ve already forced prospect Alex Freeland into what is essentially an everyday role to make up for their absences, and would exacerbate that by moving Betts to the outfield.
The absences of Edman, Hernández and Kim also remove certain options from the outfield mix that could reduce Teoscar Hernández’s exposure to right field without moving Betts off of shortstop.
Roberts said Edman will not return until his sprained right ankle can physically handle center field, which would move Andy Pages to right field and, in theory, put Hernández in left field for certain matchups. That would, in theory, also boost the lineup offensively, with Michael Conforto still providing nothing at the plate and Alex Call going 4-for-23 to start his Dodgers career after being acquired at the deadline.
There’s also the fact Betts might not even be the best defensive right fielder on the roster right now. Pages’ arm ideally puts him in right. Betts’ defensive metrics (as much as public metrics can be trusted) had not been as strong as his peak years in Boston even before he moved off the position, and he was essentially average at the position in the final month and a half of 2024 by Outs Above Average.
That’s still better than Hernández’s minus-9 Outs Above Average so far this season, but worse than Betts’ 2 Outs Above Average at a more important defensive position so far in 2025.
Roberts still acknowledged this all becomes more of a conversation if the Dodgers can get closer to full strength, anyway, before retracting some of his pointed criticism of Hernández from Monday night and doubling down on his belief Hernández can improve his range.
Advertisement
“I think, just in totality, we can all do a better job,” Roberts said. “All of us. So I just refuse to pin it on one position, one person. … That’s just not what I do. But I do believe … if there’s ways to get better on the margins, I think that way to look at it is completely fair and completely honest.
“I do know that Teo feels more comfortable in right. I know the numbers don’t speak to it this year. I’m counting on him to improve play out there. I really am. I’ll leave it at that.”
(Photo of Mookie Betts: Luke Hales / Getty Images)

argos_summary: Teoscar Hernández’s slump has become emblematic of the Los Angeles Dodgers’ recent inconsistency, prompting manager Dave Roberts to call for a reset and greater focus. Hernández’s defensive lapses and the lowest OPS of his career have drawn criticism, while injuries and mental fatigue are cited as possible causes. Roberts has emphasized the need for the team to maintain intensity and “flip the switch” to win, but the Dodgers have struggled against both winning and losing teams, leaving their division lead vulnerable. The situation underscores a broader question of whether the Dodgers can sustain performance as the season progresses.
